titleStmt.title: The missing link between response selection and execution in language production

affiliation.orgName: Basque Center on Cognition, Brain and Language
BCBL. Basque Center on Cognition, Brain and Language

analytic.title: The missing link between response selection and execution in language production

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: In this review, challenges related to the measurement of word durations in language production are identified, highlighting gaps in current theoretical frameworks and the resulting difficulty in interpreting available evidence. To compensate for limited theoretical predictions regarding response durations in spoken language, we turn to other fields, such as written production and motor control, to provide informative analogies. In written production, reliable effects on durations have been observed but the field similarly suffers from the absence of clear predictions from the available models, limiting interpretations. Since word durations are the result of motor programming and execution, evidence from motor control is particularly relevant. Recent theoretical proposals suggest that planning and execution stages overlap in time, with response planning continuing even after the initiation of the motor response, making variations in durations arise from either planning or execution processes. In addition, they propose a gating mechanism to launch response initiation. Similar dynamics could be easily assumed in language production, which could help bridge the gap from response selection to response execution and extend current models of language production to account for motor execution and predict word durations. We end by outlining pending questions for the field of language production, and some recommendations to tackle them in the future.

div.p: Mental chronometry, the measurement of human behavior and, in particular, of response times to a stimulus in order to understand mental processes, was put forward by Donders (1969). Applied to language production, it has been extremely fruitful for understanding processes of syntactic encoding (e.g., Bock & Levelt, 1994;Pickering & Branigan, 1999), lexical retrieval (e.g., Costa et al., 2001;Dell & O'Seaghdha, 1992;Levelt et al., 1991), morphological encoding (e.g., Schiller & Verdonschot, 2018), and phonological encoding (e.g., Damian & Dumay, 2009;Meyer, 1991;Wheeldon & Levelt, 1995). However, in contrast to the interest in measuring response times (i.e., the time from stimulus presentation to response onset), there has been less interest in measuring response durations (i.e., the time from response onset to offset), even in studies of motor control (Pfister et al., 2023;Rosenbaum, 2005). In language production, little is known about what determine word durations, i.e., the time taken to produce an entire word from onset to offset, and how word durations relate to response times.

The present review aims to identify challenges related to interpreting word durations in language production. In particular, a solid theoretical framework that would describe the processing stages from stimulus presentation to the utterance of a word and predict word durations is still missing. Current models of language production do not include processing stages for motor execution and control, making the interpretation of available results on word durations challenging. In order to compensate for the existing gaps in models of speech production, we will turn to related fields to look for informative analogies. Written production research has also provided results on word durations, which will be used to interrogate whether similar processing stages should be expected across the spoken and written modalities of language production. Moreover, since durations must be the result of motor programming and execution, current advances in the field of motor control, in particular using perceptual decision-making tasks that have been shown to share processes with language production (e.g., Riès et al., 2011), will be examined. The hope is that these findings will help fill the gap between response times and durations in spoken language production research and inform future directions in our field.

The goal here is not to provide an exhaustive review of either written production or motor control research but rather to point to interesting initiatives in different fields that might shed light on the issue of word durations in language production. Therefore, it is beyond the scope of this review to discuss measures of speech production, such as phonetic and articulatory measures that are below the word level (e.g., phonetic distortions, acoustic measures, articulatory imaging) or pertain to specific contexts of production (e.g., language acquisition, multilingualism), although they constitute valuable results (Alderete et al., 2021;Baese-Berk & Goldrick, 2009;Drake & Corley, 2015;Gavino & Goldrick, 2023;Goldrick et al., 2021;Goldrick & Blumstein, 2006;Heisler et al., 2010;Pouplier & Goldstein, 2010, to cite only a few).

div.head: Definition of the problem
div.p: Language production models are very informative for predicting response times (RT, i.e., the time from stimulus presentation to the onset of speech, e.g., Dell, 1986;Levelt et al., 1999), but much less for predicting response durations (i.e., the time from the onset of speech to the end of production). A common assumption is that response times map onto lexical retrieval, phonological encoding, and articulatory planning of at least the first segment of the word, while word durations encompass the online articulatory planning and execution of the rest of the word segments (Romani et al., 2022). Yet it is not entirely clear whether word durations are the best measure to assess the later stages of word production, or what processing stage(s) word durations would map onto (Buchwald, 2013).

An important debate concerns what determines word production durations. One way of tackling this issue has been to examine whether the time it will take to pronounce a word is planned and pre-set before response initiation (i.e., speech onset), or instead whether word duration is subject to online planning and/or interference as we speak (see Kawamoto et al., 1999). This contrast lays out the following predictions:

• If durations are pre-set, they should be defined at the initiation of articulation and not subject to change after that point. In that case, the relationship between RT and duration should be fixed and specific.
• If durations are subject to online planning, it opens further questions, such as:
What factors can influence durations online? Are they the same factors that determine RT? If so, do they have the same effects on RT and durations?

• A combination of both predictions would assume that durations are pre-set before articulation begins, but can also be subject to online planning and interference during articulation. This leaves predictions more open, and it would need to be determined in which conditions durations would be sensitive to interference or not. Table 1 summarizes the results obtained on word durations and RT in spoken word production. The table is organized by the directionality of the effects (e.g., facilitatory or inhibitory) on durations and on RT. For each combination of effects, the interpretation of the pattern of results (from the original study) and the experimental manipulation that led to the results are indicated. The task is always single word production from a picture or a written word, but manipulations are diverse. They include characteristics of the item being named (e.g., word frequency, phonological neighborhood density), or conditions in which it is named: with overlap between items (semantic or phonological), presence of primes or distractors (e.g., Stroop).

div.head: How have effects on durations been interpreted?
div.p: Manipulations also include task demands, that can make the task easier (e.g., item repetition) or harder (e.g., time pressure, naming on a tempo), or recruit working memory (e.g., delayed naming, reversed naming -naming the other item of a pair).

Interpretations then largely fall into two categories: either on the mechanism that led to the results (e.g., facilitation or disruption of a given process, speed-accuracy tradeoff) or on the underlying system itself, i.e., whether response execution is completely separate from response planning ("staged system", Kello et al., 2000) or whether the system allows for some amount of overlap between planning and execution ("cascaded system", Kello et al., 2000). Table 1 should be highlighted. First, a good number of studies have evaluated whether a highly reliable effect on RT could also impact word durations using semantic interference, i.e., word production in the context of 6 competition between semantically related words. Results so far are mixed. While semantic interference is reported on RT across the board, both null results and interference have been found on durations (Damian, 2003;Fink et al., 2018;Goldrick et al., 2018). This shows that a very reliable effect on RT is not always reliably found on durations. Authors have proposed that effects might be detected on durations only if disruption at the lexical level yielding the effects on RT is strong enough, in line with the idea that durations "inherit" effects from lexical selection (Fink et al., 2018).

div.head: Several elements of
div.p: Second, some manipulations targeted task demands rather than linguistic factors. In particular, several studies manipulated response preparation time by adding a time deadline or a delay to initiate the response. Imposing a deadline on response latencies is likely to push participants to initiate their response before it is fully programmed (see also Griffin, (2003) for similar reasoning in two-word utterance planning). Kello et al. (2000) reported such a pattern and concluded that according to task demands, the relation between articulation and linguistic processing could vary, with speech onset starting earlier and articulation then overlapping with linguistic processing stages in a parallel manner when time pressure increased. Without time pressure, they argued for serial or staged processing between linguistic retrieval and articulation, evidenced by null effects on durations. Further evidence comes from imposing an increasingly fast tempo on word naming which linearly sped up durations (Kello, 2004).The proposal is appealing although there have been several failures to replicate these results (Damian, 2003; see also Goldrick et al., 2018).

While adding a delay before response initiation should decrease durations, either no difference or lengthened durations were reported, leading Romani et al. (2022) to argue for online articulatory planning (see also Kello, 2004).

Third, what is striking from Table 1 is that every possible combination of effects on RT and duration has been reported. Effects of opposite directions on RT and durations are the most difficult to account for within current cognitive models of word production. Assuming that all reported results are reliable and need to be accounted for, their diversity makes it impossible for a single model to account for all of them, unless the system is flexible, in particular to accommodate task demands. Models including a flexible criterion to launch response initiation might be an answer. For instance, it has been proposed that the system could shift from waiting for the whole word vs. only for the initial phoneme to be programmed to initiate a response according to task demands (Griffin, 2003;Kawamoto et al., 1998Kawamoto et al., , 1999. Others have assumed the locus of the criterion to be on lexical selection rather than response initiation (Nozari & Hepner, 2019b, 2019a).

This brief overview shows the limitations of interpretations in the scope of the current theoretical models, despite assumptions being usually well laid out by the authors of each study. Note. 1 Kawamoto et al. (1999): word duration is divided in onset and rhyme durations, with facilitation observed on onset durations but no significant effect on rhyme durations. 2 Goldrick et al. (2018): no significant effect on RT, interference on errors, facilitation on durations.

div.head: Contribution of handwriting and typing research
div.p: Despite shared lexico-semantic representations, written production has different characteristics from spoken production. First, our lifetime experience with writing is lower than with speech, and writing is also typically slower than speech. Second, the co-existence of phonological and orthographic representations in writing might prompt different activation dynamics, although the argument has been made that the processing stages that constitute the underlying cognitive architecture are similar overall (Bonin et al., 2015;Pinet & Nozari, 2018). Modality-specific working memory stores have been postulated to hold information between stages: a graphemic working memory -or buffer-holding orthographic representations in writing (Caramazza et al., 1987), and a phonological working memory holding phonological representations in speech (Zahn et al., 2022). Still, it is reasonable to expect that the language system solves the problem of response selection and execution in similar ways across the spoken and written modalities, making it relevant to compare results from these two modalities Damian & Stadthagen-Gonzalez, 2009;Goldrick et al., 2010). It must be noted that, in contrast with spoken production, instead of reporting full word durations, written durations are usually normalized by number of (key)strokes, to account for slower production and the predominant influence of number of letters.

Overall, response durations in writing have been more systematically assessed than in speech. There are converging results across written modalities (i.e., handwriting and typing), such as the detrimental effect of phono-orthographic irregularity on written durations, reflecting the inherent conflict between lexical and sublexical routes (Bonin et al., 2015). As both phonological and orthographic representations are activated during written production (e.g., Damian et al., 2011), they can compete if the sublexical conversion of the phonological representation into letters doesn't match the irregular spelling retrieved from the lexicon. Typically, uncommon spellings (i.e., orthographic irregularity) lead to both lengthened RT and durations (Palmis et al., 2019;Planton et al., 2017;Roux et al., 2013). The effect depends on the position of the irregularity in the word: it is observed on both RT and durations if irregularity is at the beginning of the word, while it is visible only on durations of the final part of the word, but not on RT if irregularity is at the end of the word. Similar orthographic effects have been reported on typed durations, such as inhibitory effect of orthographic complexity (Cerni & Job, 2022), as well as facilitatory effect of orthographic neighborhood (Scaltritti et al., 2016).

By definition, phono-orthographic irregularity can only be assessed between different words: some words are regular and others are irregular. When factors were instead manipulated within items (i.e., the same item produced in different conditions), more contrasting results were observed. Similar to findings in speech, a facilitatory effect of immediate repetition has been reported on written durations, reflected in lower durations on subsequent repetitions of a word (Delattre et al., 2006; in speech, see Jacobs et al., 2015). However, semantic interference, Stroop interference, and phonological priming manipulations yielded null results on handwritten or typed word durations (Damian & Freeman, 2008;Damian & Stadthagen-Gonzalez, 2009;Logan & Zbrodoff, 1998;Scaltritti et al., 2017). In particular, phonological priming did not yield facilitation on durations, although it did on RT, both on single word and adjective-noun phrases (Damian & Stadthagen-Gonzalez, 2009). Similarly, semantic priming yielded null results on typed durations, despite significant facilitation on typed RT (Scaltritti et al., 2017).

Research questions surrounding written durations have been framed as whether linguistic planning is over when written execution begins, or whether it is still ongoing and can influence response execution. Significant effects of psycholinguistic variables on durations are typically taken as supporting evidence in favor of parallel or concurrent activation of linguistic planning and execution processes, coined

"cascading" between central and peripheral processing levels (e.g., Delattre et al., 2006;Roux et al., 2013;Van Galen, 1990). Going back to the predictions laid out for spoken production above, it would correspond to online planning of response durations subject to interference from the same factors as the ones determining RT.

This framework explains well effects that go in the same direction on RT and durations, such as those prompted by phono-orthographic irregularity, which might have directed attention towards results consistent on both measures (e.g., Delattre et al., 2006;Roux et al., 2013). The effect of irregularity arising early or late according to the position of the irregularity in the word also fits with the online planning of durations. Yet, this framework falls short in interpreting effects in opposite directions that have also been reported (e.g., Cerni & Job, 2022;Pinet et al., 2016). Moreover, it does not directly answer the question of whether word durations are pre-planned, although null results on written durations have been interpreted as resulting from advanced planning of the full word or noun phrase, similar to speech (e.g., Damian & Stadthagen-Gonzalez, 2009; see Damian, 2003 in speech). In addition, important specifications about the relation between processing stages remain unclear: Is cascading postulated between all processing levels? (cf., arguments for limited interactivity in speech, Goldrick, 2006;Goldrick & Rapp, 2007;Rapp et al., 2014; and in writing above the orthographic level, Bonin et al., 2012).

Should feedback connections from execution back to lexical/orthographic levels also be postulated? (see Buchwald & Falconer, 2014;Goldrick et al., 2010;McCloskey et al., 2006 for evidence for feedback from the letter level to lexical level). Where would working memory stores such as the graphemic buffer stand in a fully cascaded model? (see Kandel, 2023 for a discussion).

The comparison between results obtained in spoken and written production suffers from several limitations. The most reliable results on written durations have been obtained with between-item manipulations using formal properties of words (e.g., phono-orthographic consistency), where the same letter or bigram is compared between two words matched on their psycholinguistic properties. Effects yielded by such manipulations might not be directly comparable to within-item manipulations such as semantic interference or phonological priming that more directly target the activation level of a lexical item (Buchwald & Falconer, 2014). Moreover, only a few studies reported written durations in picture naming (Damian & Stadthagen-Gonzalez, 2009;Torrance et al., 2017), possibly following a tradition in neuropsychology favoring spelling and dictation tasks, but making results difficult to compare to spoken language production where picture naming is more widely used.

It also remains unclear how effects observed on written RT and durations relate, as their relationship has rarely been evaluated directly (but see Roux et al., 2013 for a positive correlation of raw measures). More elaborate analyses such as mediation analyses (Buz & Jaeger, 2016) or inclusion of RT in models of durations (Fink et al., 2018) are still missing. Direct comparisons between speaking and writing are likely to be a promising avenue of research to compare language production not only between output modalities but also at different levels of experience (e.g., . For instance, we recently reported a high correlation between spoken and typed RT but no correlation on durations (Pinet & Martin, 2023). The direct comparison of handwriting and typing has also suggested some differences between written modalities (Cerni & Job, 2022, 2023, which could point to differences in processing stages or in the way information flows from one stage to another, although it remains to be established whether these effects stem from differential experience and expertise, time scales (handwriting has shorter RT, but longer durations than typing), and/or representations that are specific to each modality (e.g., graphomotor related to the writing movement). Manipulating the same factors across spoken and written modalities should help to build a comprehensive picture of the processes at play.

Although written durations have been more consistently evaluated and significant effects have been reliably reported, the field suffers from similar limitations as spoken language production with too many gaps in the available theoretical proposals to account for all the results.

div.head: Contribution of motor control research
div.p: As put forward in this special issue, language production constitutes a motor action (or movement sequence) stemming from a linguistic representation. Motor control research usually focuses on the study of simpler movements, such as buttons presses, prompted by the categorization of a stimulus. The selection of a motor response is theorized through decision making models, one of the most well-known being the evidence accumulation model (Ratcliff, 1978). Recent initiatives have been bringing action and cognition closer, after having been traditionally conceptualized separately (e.g., Cisek, 2007;Serrien et al., 2007). Therefore, results in motor control are likely to inform the relationship between response selection and execution in language production. In contrast with the previous sections, the focus will be on evaluating theoretical proposals rather than experimental results, in particular regarding the overlap between response selection and execution stages, and predictions about movement durations.

Recent evidence suggests that the response system needs to incorporate an element of flexibility regarding when a response is initiated, for instance to account for task-related differences. According to Wispinski et al. (2020), a flexible system can be achieved if decision making does not stop when a response is initiated.

Instead, decision making constitutes a gradual process that is ongoing from stimulus presentation to the end of the movement. They argue that there is nothing special about the time of response initiation, in the sense that competition between response alternatives occurs before and after this point. This does not entail that decision making cannot be over before a movement is made in some cases, especially if the movement is very brief; but the authors describe decision making as a dynamic, graded, and distributed process, with cascades of information flowing up and down processing levels, to and from sensory and motor areas. reaching that threshold sends information to the muscles to begin motor execution.

Importantly, although they differ in their computational implementation, both models include a gating mechanism to launch response initiation. In that sense, response initiation is not ballistic, but follows evidence accumulation, which gives some control and flexibility over the threshold required to launch a response.

The planning-control model (Glover, 2004) they are most likely to be both active at the beginning of a movement (although precise time courses are not described in the model). Slower movement durations can then originate from either planning or control processes. Following Fitt's Law (Fitts, 1954), planning processes can slow down a movement if its execution is deemed difficult, for instance when reaching a small target: if the task goal is complex, slowing down movement time leaves control processes more time to operate during movement execution (Glover, 2004). Slowing down can also come from control processes, such as deceleration during movement execution. Overall, long movements leave more room for control processes to take over and are more likely to be produced in a different way than the way they were planned. In line with the idea that movement durations can be controlled by different processes than RT, Kello et al. (2007) demonstrated uncorrelated fluctuations of RT and durations in four experiments. They argued that RT and durations are coordinated rather than correlated, again allowing for more flexibility in the system.

When studying motor control, using mostly simple movements and choice reactiontime tasks might restrict the results that can be obtained. In particular, models of decision making usually consider movements as ballistic, such that reaction time and response duration are virtually treated as the same value (Wispinski et al., 2020).

The experimental tasks that are commonly used to study decision making do not allow for movements to take time as they do in more realistic situations, which constitutes a strong limitation to study movement as it unfolds over time and the control processes overseeing execution (Pfister et al., 2023;Wispinski et al., 2020).

Dynamic response methods (e.g., mouse tracking), rather than simple ballistic movements (e.g., keypresses) have already been used successfully, revealing signs of response conflict in the movement times and trajectories (Calderon et al., 2018;Erb et al., 2021;Tseng & Damian, 2023). As such, language production, whether through speech or writing, naturally constitutes a dynamic response method, if durations are taken into account.

Next, we review previous attempts at integrating motor control methods or theories with language production, before proposing our own vision of how to integrate theoretical proposals from the different fields.

div.head: Attempts at integrating language production and motor research
div.p: The desire to integrate the fields of language production and motor control has been growing, as demonstrated by this special issue, and successful parallels have already been made. Hickok proposed an ambitious integration of forward models of motor control in language production frameworks (Hickok, 2012(Hickok, , 2014Hickok et al., 2011; see also Wolpert & Kawato, 1998). Unfortunately, his proposal does not include specific predictions for word durations. To address the debate on the need for competition in lexical selection, Nozari & Hepner, 2019b proposed to integrate signal detection theory and criterion setting for lexical selection. However, their proposal also does not include an explicit discussion of potential consequences for word durations.

Some direct attempts at fitting models of decision making, such as evidence accumulation models (Ratcliff, 1978), to speech latencies have been made (Anders et al., 2015). However, this approach still relied on RT distribution only, and used a separate parameter, the non-decision time, i.e., time external to the decision accumulation process, to account for motor-related processes (see Weindel et al., 2022). Interestingly, this parameter of the model did not capture any effect of semantic interference in a healthy adult population, although it did in a clinical population of patients with prefrontal cortex lesions (Anders et al., 2017). In addition to RT and/or accuracy, it can be informative to include further parameters in decision making models, such as corrections or changes of mind. These correspond to a case when an action towards one alternative is initiated but is followed by a change in trajectory, usually a correction towards the correct alternative. Corrections have prompted the development of new decision-making models, which do include motor execution processes (Wispinski et al., 2020). This could easily benefit language production, as corrections and the processes leading to them have also been extensively studied in spoken language (e.g., Gauvin & Hartsuiker, 2020;Nooteboom & Quené, 2020).

Response time fractioning is another method from motor control research that has been applied to language production. It consists of dividing response time into premotor and motor times using the time when the motor command is received at the target muscles as indexed by the onset of electromyographic (EMG) activity. This has been applied to the speech signal, using EMG from oro-facial muscles to decompose spoken latencies. For instance, Riès et al. (2012) found motor times to be longer in naming than reading (but see van der Linden et al., 2014 for methodological issues and additional recommendations for EMG onset detection during articulation, and Riès et al., 2015 for a corrigendum). More recently, EMG decomposition of RT in a lexical decision task showed that both premotor and motor times were sensitive to the lexicality of the stimulus (Dendauw et al., 2024;Scaltritti et al., 2023). This result was interpreted as the continuity of accumulation processes during response execution. It can be noted that the interpretations that have been formulated about premotor and motor times reflecting different cognitive processes are similar to the ones we reviewed above for RT and duration.

Implementing methods from motor control to language production data, such as fitting decision-making models or response time fractioning, have been successful endeavors. Theoretical proposals from motor control have been important for deepening our understanding of response times, and could be instrumental for predicting durations as well. In the previous sections, we have outlined theoretical proposals on the relation between response selection and execution that we believe can help fill the gap in theoretical models of language production research. In decision making, it now seems established that the decision process continues after the initiation of the motor response, arguing for the overlap of planning and execution stages (Wispinski et al., 2020). There is no reason to believe that this would not also be the case in language production, meaning that linguistic planning stages would still be active during response execution, as it has been proposed in written production (e.g., Roux et al., 2013). Moreover, slower movement durations are deemed to originate from either planning or control processes, especially at the beginning of the movement (Glover, 2004). Bringing this framework to word production durations, it fits with the last case we put forward of pre-planned durations that are open to online planning during response execution. There would be two possible sources of variation for durations, during planning or execution, especially at the beginning of the word when both processes are more likely to overlap (e.g., Palmis et al., 2019). Finally, several proposals include an adaptive threshold or gating mechanism responsible for launching response initiation (Calderon et al., 2018;Dendauw et al., 2024). In language production, a flexible criterion for word onset or lexical selection has previously been suggested (Kawamoto et al., 1998(Kawamoto et al., , 1999Nozari & Hepner, 2019b). The implementation of a flexible criterion for initiating the response could account for opposite effects on RT and durations: if a response is initiated earlier, RT is shorter but duration can be similar or longer.

div.head: Pending questions
div.p: From the review of the spoken and written language production literature and the integration of findings from motor control, we wish to outline pending questions for our field:

• What features can allow for task-related flexibility in response initiation in the production system? What is the role of domain-general factors? Is their contribution independent, additive, or interactive with linguistic processes?

• Are there differences between modalities of language production? Can one allencompassing model account for all modalities? Are differences to be expected according to experience and expertise, time scales, and modality-specific representations?
• What is the role of working memory stores (i.e., buffers)? How do modalityspecific buffers relate (e.g., phonological working memory in speech, graphemic buffer in writing)?
• Can motor execution influence linguistic planning, for instance through feedback connections from response execution to higher processing levels?
• What processes do response durations index? Can we distinguish planning and control processes by assessing durations?
• Are effects on RT and durations correlated? Are there effects on durations above and beyond effects on RT?
• How do individual differences in linguistic processing and motor planning and execution interact?

div.head: Recommendations for future research
div.p: In order to address the pending questions outlined, we have identified several areas on which future studies should focus. First, from the reviewed studies, some experiment manipulations appear more likely to yield valuable results. For instance, within-item manipulations allow for more controlled conditions and robust results than between-item manipulations. Moreover, when a response deadline is applied, it should include the full duration of the response (from stimulus presentation to the end of the production) and not only response initiation, to prompt flexibility about the time a response is initiated. Both recommended manipulations would address the issue of flexibility in the system such as whether word durations depend on the context and/or condition of production, or how much they are sensitive to time constraints.

Second, measures can still be improved, already by the simple commitment of measuring and reporting response durations. Currently, too few studies systematically assess durations and more evidence is still needed. Even if theoretical predictions can be hard to formulate, more duration data should be gathered and publicly shared. Moreover, special care should be taken when measuring RT. In some cases, RT might partly include response execution, as articulation can start before phonation depending on articulatory features (Fargier et al., 2018;Krause & Kawamoto, 2020). This is also true for typing (Logan & Crump, 2011), but not in handwriting or button presses, and should be taken into account for cross-modal comparisons.

Finally, accumulating data will prove useful only if relevant analyses that address specific research questions on the underlying system are performed. In addition to analyzing RT and durations, studies that directly assess their relationship are needed (Kello, 2004). Several ways to do so have already been proposed:

correlation (e.g., Roux et al., 2013), mediation (e.g., Buz & Jaeger, 2016), inclusion of RT or residuals from the RT analysis in the analysis of durations (e.g., Fink et al., 2018). Moreover, assessing positional effects should help determine the range of overlap between planning and control processes, expected to be stronger at the beginning than the end of a word (Glover, 2004;Kawamoto et al., 2015). This is technically easier to do in writing than in speech (e.g., Palmis et al., 2019). Machinelearning algorithms might alleviate this data processing cost in speech . Overall, these analyses would address important questions about structural properties of the system and what RT and durations map onto.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In summary, the challenges associated with the interpretation of results on word durations are likely related to the difficulty for current models of language production to account for response execution, whether in speech or in writing. Recent findings in motor control have quite convincingly established that response planning does not stop when a response is initiated. Elements such as a gating mechanism that can allow for task-related flexibility in response initiation should be implemented in models of language production to account for motor execution and predict word durations. Overall, we are convinced that bringing together findings from different but related fields of research such as motor control and language production is crucial to reach a better understanding of cognitive processing.

figure.figDesc: Two recent models have proposed specific elements in the way processing stages are arranged that can allow for flexible response initiation. First, the unfolding action model(Calderon et al., 2018) posits an "adaptive" information flow between the final cognitive and the motor processing stages, providing an alternative to the traditional views of continuous or thresholded information flow. It consists of a threshold to launch response initiation that adapts to the amount of activation of each response alternative, gated by an external structure (the subthalamic nucleus). In consequence, cognitive processing need not be finished before launching an action, meaning that the adaptive flow can account for results in favor of both thresholded and continuous information flow between cognitive and motor stages. Moreover, it can separate action selection from execution, for instance if an action needs to be withheld before launching. Second,Dendauw et al. (2024) proposed an update to the evidence accumulation model(Ratcliff, 1978) with a dual-stage dual-threshold model. Specifically, they incorporated a motor preparation stage that acts as a filtered accumulation process, again between the decision and motor execution stages. This stage includes a threshold, distinct from the decision-making threshold;

figure.figDesc: Summary table of the pattern of effects reported on duration and RT. For each combination of effect, are indicated the interpretation from the original study along with the experimental manipulation (task in parenthesis). Grey cells outline opposite effects on RT and duration. Factors that could affect general cognitive processing are underlined.

row.cell: Speed-accuracy trade-off, direct influence on durations
(continuous and blocked naming), (2) Stroop interference, (3) tempo-

figure.figDesc: also postulates significant overlap between planning and execution processes. It dissociates the planning and control stages, showing that they are associated with distinct brain networks and visual representations. At the planning stage, adaptive motor programs are selected and initiated to fulfil task goals. Then, the control stage aims to minimize the spatial error of the movement, adjusting its trajectory if necessary. Both stages overlap in time:
